column4: Tough question, and i'll try and explain the most apt i can. I have an ntfs internal hdd. it used to house a windows partition, with tons of personal stuff that i would love to be able to recover. I hooked it up under linux awhile back, enabled read/write access with ntfs-3g the right way, and was able to view my files. even though read/WRITE was on, i made the mistake of moving a file from one ntfs partition to another and it fr
ied my drive. now no matter what (trust me when i say i've exhausted my software recovery/formatting/zero wiping options) i cannot access it in linux or windows. Any suggestions?
decorate a shoebox, place hdd in box, say last words . . .
i saw that you can buy the circuitry that is on the outside of the hdd, would that have anything to do with partition tables? because i'm pretty sure that the lack of the part. tables is the problem.
